text: - Adjective An adjective gives a description of a noun.
- Adverb An adverb describes the action of a sentence or an adjective or another adverb.
- Apostrophe' We use the apostrophe for possession and contractions.
- Article An article comes before a noun. It tells if the noun is definite or indefinite. The definite article is the. The indefinite articles are  $a$  and an.
- Base Form The base form, sometimes called the "simple" form, of the verb has no tense. It has no ending (-s or -ed): be, go, eat, take, write.
You shouldn't talk in the library.

list_items: Capital Letter ABCDEFG...
Comma
- Comparative Form A comparative form of an adjective or adverb is used to compare two things.

text: My house is bigger than your house.
Her husband drives faster than she does.
- Complement The complement of the sentence is the information after the verb if it is not an object. It completes the verb phrase.
- Consonant The following letters are consonants:  $b, c, d, f, g, h, j, k, l, m, n, p, q, r, s, t, v, w, x, y, z$ .
Note:  $y$  is sometimes considered a vowel, as in the word syllable.
- Contraction A contraction is two words joined with an apostrophe.
- Count Noun Count nouns are nouns that we can count. They have a singular and a plural form.
- Frequency Words Frequency words (e.g., always, usually, often, sometimes, rarely, seldom, hardly ever, and never) tell how often an action happens.
- Imperative An imperative sentence gives a command or instructions. An imperative sentence omits the subject pronoun you.
- Infinitive An infinitive is to + the base form.
You need to be here on time.
- Modal The modal verbs are can, could, shall, should, will, would, may, might, and must.

- Nonaction Verb A nonaction verb has no action. We do not use a continuous tense (be + verb -ing) with a nonaction verb. Nonaction verbs include: believe, cost, care, have, hear, know, like, love, matter, mean, need, own, prefer, remember, see, seem, think, understand, want, and sense-perception verbs.
- Noncount Noun A noncount noun is a noun that we don't count. It has no plural form.
We had a lot of homework.
- Noun A noun is a person (brother), a place (kitchen), or a thing (table). Nouns can be either count (1 table, 2 tables) or noncount (money, water).
My sisters live in New York.
I get money from my parents.
- Object The object of the sentence follows the verb. It receives the action of the verb.
- Object Pronoun Use object pronouns (me, you, him, her, it, us, and them) after a verb or preposition.
I saw the movie. Let's talk about it.
- Phrase A group of words that go together.
Last month my sister came to visit.
There is a red car in front of my house.
- Plural means "more than one." A plural noun usually ends with -s or -es.
- Possessive Form Possessive forms show ownership or relationship.
Mary's coat is in the closet.

- Preposition A preposition is a connecting word. Some common prepositions are: about, above, across, after, around, as, at, away, before, behind, below, by, down, for, from, in, into, like, of, off, on, out, over, to, under, up, and with.
The book is on the table.
- Present Participle The present participle of a verb is the base form + -ing.
- Pronoun A pronoun takes the place of a noun.
Dorota bought a new car. She bought it last week.
John likes Mary, but she doesn't like him.

list_items: - Punctuation The use of specific marks, such as commas and periods, to make ideas within writing clear.
- Question Mark ?
- Regular Verb A regular verb forms the simple past with -ed.

text: - -s Form A simple present verb that ends in -s or -es.
- Sentence A sentence is a group of words that contains a subject! and a verb and gives a complete thought.
NOT A SENTENCE: When she came home
- Simple Form of Verb The simple form of the verb, also called the "base" form, has no tense; it never has an -s, -ed, or -ing ending.
I can't find his phone number.
- Subject The subject of the sentence tells who or what the sentence is about.
My sister bought a new car.
- Subject Pronoun We use a subject pronoun (I, you, he, she, it, we, you, they) before a verb.
- Superlative The superlative form of an adjective or adverb shows the number one item in a group of three or more.
January is the coldest month of the year.
You have the best seat in the room.
1 In an imperative sentence, the subject you is omitted: Sit down. Come here.
- Syllable A syllable is a part of a word that has only one vowel sound. (Some words have only one syllable.)
- Tense Tense shows when the action of the sentence happened. Verbs have different tenses.
SIMPLE PRESENT: She usually drives to work.
FUTURE: She is going to drive tomorrow.
PRESENT CONTINUOUS: She is driving now.
- Verb A verb is the action of the sentence. The verb be connects.
He runs fast. I speak English. You are late.
- Vowel The following letters are vowels:  $a, e, i, o, u$ .  $Y$  is sometimes considered a vowel (for example, in the word mystery).
